messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: goin' Japanese
messages.msgSnippet: I m going to have to agree with Jinsoo. I m presently taking a College level Japanese course. I swear to god they make absolutely beautiful blades and fittings
messages.messageBody:
I'm going to have to agree with Jinsoo. I'm presently
taking a College level Japanese course. I swear to god
they make absolutely beautiful blades and fittings but
SHIT they need to stick to one method of numbering and
grammar rules. And to truely learn Japanese you have
to learn Romanji, Hirigana, Katagana, and Kanji so
that's four different languages in one. Oh yea and
things that are flat are counted differently than
those that are round. What the Hell is up with that?!?
Best advice get a tutor.

Bob R

--- Jinsoo Kim <jinsoo.kim@...> wrote:
> Richard,
>
> Find the private tutor. That will be the best for
> you. As Japanese
> grammar is completely different from English, it
> will blow out your
> head. Nice tutor will guide you much better and can
> amplify your
> interest about this field.
>
> Jinsoo
>
>


=====
Check out "Cowboy" Bob's Books & Things at:
http://asia.geocities.com/gentleman9/index.html

messages.subject: Re: goin' Japanese
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, Find the private tutor. That will be the best for you. As Japanese grammar is completely different from English, it will blow out your head. Nice
messages.messageBody:
Richard,

Find the private tutor. That will be the best for you. As Japanese
grammar is completely different from English, it will blow out your
head. Nice tutor will guide you much better and can amplify your
interest about this field.

Jinsoo

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] goin' Japanese
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, According to the Defense Agency Foreign Language School in Santa Cruz, the only more difficult language to learn than Japanese is Chinese for us. I
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard,

According to the Defense Agency Foreign Language School in Santa Cruz, the
only more difficult language to learn than Japanese is Chinese for us. I
would recommend college courses as a start and then self study of the kanji
related to swords.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: Richard George [mailto:rkg@...]
Sent: Thursday, April 24, 2003 1:21 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] goin' Japanese


Hi,

This is only peripherally related to sword study, but here goes...

I've pretty much read through everything sword related that I can find
that's printed in English, so I guess its time to learn Japanese -
The question I have is what's the least time consuming way to do this? I
know this probably sounds stupid, but
I've studied several other languages in the past (grade school, high
school, etc.,), and it seemed to be a
fairly drawn out/painful affair, and I was debatin' whether to just sign
up for a course at the local college or what...

thanks,

rkg
(Richard George)
